Maritime '89
So it doesn't quite rhyme, but who
said it had to? "Maritime '89" is
the theme of this year's Spring Fair,
and if someone suggests the concept
of Maritime to you and you start
thinking of killer sharks or Alaskan
oil spills, you're probably missing out.
Each year, over 100,000 visitors
flock to the Homewood campus for a
weekend of festivities, including
arts and crafts displays, food,
beer, soda, children's rides, an 8-K
run, and many other kinds of
entertainment.
The success of Fair depends on the
efforts of those who create it and,
as any upperclassman will dryly

remember, the cooperation of the
weather. This year's Fair will feature
more arts and crafts and food
vendors than recent Fairs, as well as
many new activities, including the
christening of the U.S.S. Hopkins at
the opening ceremonies, and a
treasure hunt.
As in the past, the News-Letter is
devoting much of its coverage this
week to Spring Fair. Articles appear
in the news, features, and arts
sections. A complete listing appears
below. We hope you enjoy our
coverage of Fair, as well as the Fair
itself.

Lacrosse, baseball teams enjoy stellar spring
Third quarter lightning propels
men's lax past North Carolina
by Patrick Furey
The Johns Hopkins lacrosse juggernaut
continued to roll last weekend, as it broke
a 5-5 halftime tie by outscoring North
Carolina 7-1 in the third quarter en route
to a 16-10 victory. The win was the fourteenth consecutive in the regular season for
the Blue Jays and the fourth straight over
the Tar Heels.
Hopkins, which is now 6-0 and ranked
number one in both the USILA and Sun
polls, jumped out to a 1-0 lead just 1:06
into the game when senior midfielder
Brendan Kelly scored off an assist from
Jeff Ihm. The Tar Heels answered right
back, however, scoring three unanswered
goals, including two by attackman Neill
Redfern.
The two teams began trading goals for
the rest of the first half, as Hopkins failed
to control the tempo and run their ball-

control offense. After goals by Johns
Wilkens and Matt Panetta had tied the
game for Hopkins at the close of the first
quarter, Dennis Goldstein put the Tar
Heels back on top 4-3 by scoring on a fast
break just ten seconds into the second
quarter. Wilkens once again evened the
score 2:54 into the quarter, and after each
team tallied to make it 5-5, neither Hopkins
nor Carolina scored for the final 8:20 of
the first half.
"We did not execute well at all in the
first half of the ball game," commented
Hopkins Coach Don Zimmerman. "We
weren't doing things the way we should be
doing them. The only thing that encouraged me was that we weren't playing fundamentally sound lacrosse, and the score
was tied."

Lonial named '89
Young Trustee
by Gregory W. Fortsch
A native of Louisville, KY,
Sagar
Lonial
is
a
biology/philosophy major who
will graduate in June and attend
medical school in the fall. In addition to these accomplishments,
Lonial has another unique distinction of which to be proud. He has
been chosen as Young Trustee for
the Class of 1989.
The process began in March
when sophomores, juniors, and
seniors voted for the Young
Trustee, choosing five of twelve
candidates on the ballot. Before
voting, each Young Trustee candidate was required to submit an
application entailing any relevant
biographical information, his
field of study, interests, and extracurricular activities, both at
Hopkins and elsewhere.
After two sets of balloting, the
five remaining trustee candidates
went to the Nominating Committee of the Board of trustees,

which interviewed each of the
five finalists.
Following the interviewing
process, the Nominating Committee voted on which candidate
best suited the position of Young
Trustee, and submitted their
recommendation to the Board of
Trustees. Lonial was their choice.
The Trustees approved the
nomination Monday.
A housemaster for two years as
well as an admissions intern and
member of the Blue Key Society, Lonial explained, "This is an
important time in the University's
future, with the new president
and the Five-Year Plan. I am excited to be a part of what will
ultimately be the future of
Hopkins."
Lonial decided to run for
Young Trustee because "I've enjoyed working with different people in many areas and I wanted
to continue. I will now be active
in a new and interesting way."

SC reviews security, blocks Hott's run for office
by Craig Freeman
Former Student Council
member Cary Gross's declaration
that "the security around campus
is not sufficient" captured the attention of Council members,
sparking a fifteen-minute discussion about Hopkins's responsibility to protect its students.
During Council's Wednesday
meeting in the Shriver Board
Room, Gross called "watching
the police extract a murder victim from the alley in St. Paul
Court" the incident that made the
issue such a pressing one. He implored Council to request tighter
security and more security vans
to protect the Hopkins
community.
Council President Lou
Giangiulio warned members not
to jump to conclusions. "When
you don't know all of the facts,
its hard to say Hopkins security
needs to be tighter," said
Giangiulio. "We need to have
more legitimate student concerns
before" Council brings the issue
to the administration.
In response to his statement,
Council members began to list
problems or criticisms with
security. Senior class representative Ty Hyderally cited a need
for more foot patrols from security. He insisted that security need

not be restricted to campus boundaries, but be widened to encounpass all of Charles Village.
Election Commissions Chair
Jen Willmann said, "Hopkins is
neglecting their responsibility to
student, off University housing."
Others added possible solutions
to security troubles, ranging from
addding more lights around campus to hiring security guards who
are licensed to carry weapons.
Before the discussion ended,
Gross brought up the point that
"Hopkins is the second largest
landowner in Baltimore. The [administration] has the power to talk
to the Baltimore City Council and
get more city police up here."
As a result of the discussion,
Council decided to have a
meeting in the AMR I Multipurpose Room with Dean of

Chris Colombo and Security
Chief Robert Larkin. The
meeting will be held sometime
during the next two weeks, and
will be open for all students to

Thirty-six in running for class officer positions
Ah, election time again. Can't
you feel it?
Three dozen candidates are
competing for class officer positions. This year's election, in addition, will also see the
reestablishment of "permanent
class officer" positions.
Seniors will elect a president,
vice president, secretary,
treasurer, and three representatives to serve on the "Class of
'89 Executive Committee,"
which will serve until the class's
Fifth Anniversary Reunion, tentatively scheduled for June, 1994.
Officers will be responsible for
organizing class activities and
keeping the Class of 1989 up to
date on ongoing activities.
Primary elections for all classes
will take place on Tuesday from

10 a.m. to 11 p.m. in the Milton

25, at the same time and place.

his primary. A representative

plus one.

Homewood rides
Maritime wave
by Steven Mizrach
"Maritime '89." When else would you see inflatable tubes on the
library?
The Spring Fair Theme Committee has been hard at work on several
projects. This year's theme committee chairs are seniors Michael Falk
and Grace Kung, and junior Nelson Tang. This year's theme is
nautical, hence the theme of Spring Fair is "Maritime '89."
The group's fifteen members have been meeting regularly since the
beginning of January. As often happens, the group dismissed some
of its initial ideas as "farfetched," such as turning Gilman Hall into
a lighthouse.
The committee decided to divide the campus into several areas: the
area in front of the Milton S. Eisenhower Library would appropriately
be called the "Beach," complete with artificial surf; especially for
kids area would become the "Pirates' Cove," with ambling buccaneers; the Upper Quad would be the "Upper Harbor," with sails
and nautical flags; and the Lower Quad would turn into "Ten Thousand Leagues Beneath the Sea," complete with underwater creatures.
Since the traditional releasing of balloons is considered too much
of an environmental hazard, Fair chairs will instead dedicate the ship
S.S. Hopkins to begin the Fair. Tony Pagnotti, a reporter for WMARTV, will have the honors. As part of nighttime entertainment, the
Glass Pavilion will be turned into a "fishbowl," and the Great Hall
will be considered the deck of a ship.
Most of the committee's work in the last few weeks has involved
decorating the campus. It has been busy designing the banners with
the different area designations, and has also been making wooden
cutouts of waves and sea creatures such as octopi and jellyfish. The
group has been trying to obtain tires to use as the hump of a giant
sea monster, and to get nautical flags from the United States Coast
Guard.
Tang said, "The Theme Committee must be really dedicated, or
Spring Fair wouldn't be a cohesive whole." He said that the many
worked with other committees to incorporate many different aspects
of Fair into the theme, so that by Friday everything would "fit in.,,
All the other committees, he pointed out, can sometimes lose sight
of the theme in the day-to-day "hustle and bustle" of arranging events,
so the theme committees must make sure that the central theme is
fully represented in the Fair.

Imported beer,
seafood available
by Andrea Marsh
"We think we've made some changes
which will help everyone in the long run,"
said Jon Aronson, co-chairman of the
Beer/Soda Committee.
The major change is that this year an imported beer, Beck's, will be available in the
beer garden.
"We're hoping it will go over real well,"
said Mike Holmes, also in charge of beer and
soda for Fair.
Last year, the seven booths in the beer
garden sold both beer and wine coolers.
However, Holmes said that the problem was
that a great demand for coolers. As a result,
this year only one booth will sell California
Coolers.
"Since wine coolers don't sell as well, it
didn't make sense for all the booths to have
them," said Aronson.
Holmes and Aronson anticipate that by concentrating all the coolers in one place, they
hope to sell the equivalent of ten kegs, more
than in past years.
Five booths will sell Schaefer beer ($1
each), one will sell Beck's ($1.25 each), and
the other booth will have California coolers
($1 each). All beer will be sold in the President's Garden.
Pepsi and Pepsi Light will be available at
booths on the Lower and Upper Quads for
seventy-five cents apiece. One soda booth will

be in the beer garden.
Aronson said he and Holmes saw no need
to change the way the soda booths were
organized.
"There was no indication of a problem,"
he said. "Of course, the fewer groups we
have, the more money each group makes, but
that also means less participation by student
groups."
Both Aronson and Holmes are excited about
the evening parties. Both Michelob and
Michelob Lite will be available for $1. In the
past, Schaefer was served both nights.
"It's the most premium beer we've ever
had," said Holmes. "We're real excited
about that."
Jenna Janss, co-chair of the Food committee, is also enthusiastic about this year's Fair.
"There's a lot more student participation than
in the past," she said.
This year, fourteen student groups are having food booths, more than in previous years.
Many other students are working with professional groups.
According to Janss, Fair has contracted for
fifty food booths, seeking more diversity.
Several new vendors include Lee's Ice Cream
and Talkin' Turkey, a deli specializing in
turkey sandwiches.
"We tried to get other things besides the
greasy fast food," she said.
More food will be in the beer garden this
year. Domino's will sell pizza, and crabs will

be available for the first time ever.
The food booths will be spread over the
Lower Quad and the Upper Quad. However,
on Monday, arrangements had to be made to
move six booths.
According to Janss, the Department of
Psychology is conducting experiments with
rats in the basement of Ames Hall. The smell
of food supposedly can affect the rats, and
could change the outcome of the experiments.
As a result, no food booths wil be located on
either side of the stairways leading to the
Lower Quad.
Psychology Professor Stewart Hulse said
that these experiments are conducted every
year, and that the problem is not new.
"We're concerned about the general health
of the animals, but this is no big deal," he
said.
Janss disagreed, however, saying that moving the booths did cause "major problems.'
She said that this year is the first that the
booths had to be moved.
"It could have been easily dealt with if it
had been brought up earlier," she said. "But
on Monday before Fair, it has really caused
some inconvenience."
The major problem with moving the booths
was that the electrical wiring that had already
been laid down had to be moved.
Janss said, however, that the problem was
handled well. "Despite the inconvenience,"
she said, everyone has been really cooperative
and supportive in trying to work out the
problem."

8-K run for early rising runners
by Bradley Cohen
The fifth annual Spring Fair 8-kilometer race is set to begin in front
of the Newton H. White Athletic Center Saturday morning. The race,
with separate men's, women's, and Hopkins divisions will wind
around the Homewood campus finishing on the track.
A relatively new activity for Spring Fair, the race will attract approximately 225 runners, according to Skip Bacon, race committee
chair. The course begins in front of the Athletic Center, proceeds
along University Parkway and then down Charles Street to Wyman
Park. The course then works its way around the back of campus and
finishes at the track.
Bacon describes the race as a "fun run on the middle ground" between a 5K and 10K race. The committee thought that an 8K race
would be challenging, but not too long. The race was originally intended to promote health, not competition, but that has not deterred
serious competitors from entering the event.
Last year's male winner was Anthony Grier, who won with a time
of 26:00. The female winner was Pat Milleson, with a time of 30:19.

Sandy Saluzary won the Hopkins division with a time of 33.05. This
year Bacon predicts the competition to be as good as last year's, if
not better.
Planning for the race began at the start of the semester with a search
for sponsors. Bacon explained his method for finding sponsors: "You
basically ask them (sponsors] how much they will give," he said.
The sponsors put up $2,000 to pay for the race.
This year's sponsors include Schaefer beer, Domino's Pizza, and
Reebok shoes. Bacon said that all of the proceeds from the race go
to benefit the homeless of Baltimore.
After finding sponsors, Bacon and his committee had to plan the
course and seek city approval. "We've been working on things one
at a time," he said. Since receiving permission from the city, the committee has been busily promoting the race and signing up participants.
Anyone may register for the race on Friday at the Spring Fair office or just before the race on Saturday morning. Registration is $9
on Friday and $10 Saturday. Bacon said that anyone who would like
to help officiate should speak with him before the race. Everyone who
works will receive a free race t-shirt.

Finally, a scant 41 days before graduation,
the senior class commencement committee has
snared a speaker. Kenneth Duberstein, former
chief of staff in the Reagan administration, will
address seniors in the afternoon of May 25.
While Duberstein is a relative unknown to
many, he will doubtless send seniors out into
the world with a rousing and challenging
address.
More interesting, perhaps, than the speaker
himself, has been the drama that has unfolded
in his selection. From late starts to lack of student participation to severe budget limitations,
the selection process has been plagued from the
very beginning. That we have snatched a
speaker from the jaws of defeat at all is tantamount to a miracle.
We should not, however, bog ourselves down
in the mire of rehashing the endless details of
this somewhat sad situation. Rather, we should
glean what lessons we can from the difficulties
that they have faced over the course of the year.
First, the senior class, if they are to attract a
speaker of reasonable caliber, ought to have
sufficient funding to support their expectations.
At present, there is $2500 budgeted for this purpose; on the lecture circuit more sought-after
speakers can fetch up to ten times as much.
For those universities that do not allot large
amounts of r9ch to comr—ncement speakers,

there is often compensation in the form of an
honorary degree for the speaker. At present,
the University has "strict policies" regarding
the granting of such degrees.
The offer of an honorary degree might
sweeten the pot for anyone considering speaking here; however, for this to occur, the
Trustees must be given advance notice and
deem the potential recipient as worthy of the
honor.
Which brings us to our final point:
possibilities for speakers must be compiled
earlier in the year than has been the practice
in years past. This year, despite the endless
disclaimers from senior class officers, there was
a serious dearth of publicity surrounding the
project. Senior Week, ostensibly the most important responsiblity of the senior class officers,
ought to be in full gear by the middle of the
first semester, soliciting opinions and compiling early lists in order to facilitate selection.
These options ought to be fully communicated
to the class throughout the year. We need only
look to the experiences of this year's class for
failures in this sort of rapport. It seemed seniors
heard little of any plan until it was a fait accompli; this individualistic style of leadership
created a sense of futility and further discouraged senior class involvement.

Securing a position
The appointment of Lou Giangiulio to the
search committee for a new Hopkins president
is an unexpected boon. After all, student contact with the Board of Trustees has been limited
to the occasional protest outside of Board
meetings. The Trustees have preferred to
receive their student viewpoint from the Young
Trustees, whose positions they created to meet
this specific need.
Events of the last year, however, have
demonstrated that undergraduates desire more
input into decisions that will affect them. The
February brouhaha over the Five-Year Plan was
due not
much to objections over the plan

itself, but rather to students' lack of involvement in its drafting and fears of being left out
of its implementation.
But it is noteworthy that the addition of a student to the committee is due to exhaustive efforts on the part of Giangiulio. Were it not for
his initiative, this in all probability would never
have occurred. We commend Giangiulio for his
energy and note the precedent that his appointment to the committee sets in terms of administrative sensitivity to student concerns. We
can only hope that it bodes well for further student involvement in the future.

Talent abounds at Showcase
by Eric Ruck
On Thursday, April 6, Shriver
Hall was filled not with a touring
band or a local performer, but
with thirteen students and student
groups, there to perform and
compete in Musical Showcase
1989, sponsored by the Office of
Residential Life.
The crowd present was
small—about the size of an
average Weekend Wonderflix
crowd on a Friday night. People
came and went as different performers took their turns; occasionally someone would disappear from the audience, only to
reappear on stage.
The Skid Row Pits played the
first set. They were, according to
senior Sharon Finberg, reminiscent of the Blues Brothers, and
lived up to their name.
"It was a little slower than I've
heard the tunes before," she said,
"but it was a good opening to the
show."

Next were Phil Garrant and
The Great Highland Bagpipe;
Michele D. Pineda playing a
Debussy toccata; Paul Zei and
James Dante playing Mancini's
"Moon River"; and Erika
Horsey's "Product of Inspiration," an original piece written
for guitar.
"She was inspired," said
senior Ginger Marth. "She had
a really rich voice, and a good
composition. The sound equipment started to fall apart, but she
didn't get phased."
Geetha Rao and Floyd Bullard
played Schubert's Military March
just before The JHU Gospel
Choir took the stage. Anyone
who has walked on the lower
quad during one of the choir's
rehearsals and heard the singing
as far away as Maryland Hall can
imagine how this group can fill a
theater with sound.
"They were very energetic,"
said Committee member John
Tennison. "I don't know whether

Hopkins students have seen that
sort of thing before."
After a ten-minute intermission, Lovejoy and his Nuclear
Band of Half-Naked & Wild
Boys, consisting of Franklin
Sechriest (Lovejoy) and Mike
Datto (ostensibly the Nuclear
Band), took the stage. Lovejoy
opened with a guitar solo that had
the audience clapping; Datto joined in on saxophone for a rendition of "Stray Cat Strut," during
which Lovejoy's maniacal
laughter drew some applause.
Master of Ceremonies Alice
Griffin then introduced Lou
Giangiulio and his accordion "so
that the Class of 1992 can be as
overwhelmed as the rest of us."
Julia G. Ro then played Mozart's
Turkish March, and was followed by Saxual 4-play, which performed Lucien Cailliet's "Fantasy and Fugue on O'Suzanna."

Difficulties occur in financing A&S
by Paul Kramer
Part two of two
Dr. Steven McLean, Hopkins's
Vice Provost for Academic Planning and Budget, who represents
Hopkins in the Ten College Consortium, noted that to deal with
economic pressures, Duke has instituted a tuition differential plan
such as Hopkins's and begun a
major capital campaign to increase its endowment. This will
raise capital for the construction
of new buildings, allow
strengthening of library and
financial aid facilities, and help
Duke move up in prestige.
Case Western Reserve, according to Provost Richard Zdonis,
former Vice Provost at Hopkins,
is more centralized than the
Hopkins model All budgeting is

done by the central administration, which allows greater
amounts of interdisciplinary
research and teaching. Each of
the three faculties (Engineering,
Science and Math, and Arts and
Social Sciences) gives a mandatory tax to a reserve fund that
supports weaker divisions, and
although the faculties are selfcontained, they are operated as a
fiscal whole; the surpluses from
each go back into the main
college.
Columbia University has a fairly decentralized model, although
not as decentralized as Hopkins.
As explained by Dr. Michael
Mooney, deputy Provost, the
University is divided into units,
or schools; each forms a budget
from endowments it specifically
receives The centralized administration has control over the

unrestricted money, which it
allocates the units according to a
formula. The "Arts and Sciences
Construct" is the largest of the
unrestricted budgetary units.
Aside from these unrestricted
allotments, the units are given
freedom to budget their own programs as they see fit. Each unit
is given a target that is the difference between budgeted
revenues and budgeted expenses.
If in one unit revenues are greater
than expected, or expenses less,
the unit may keep its profit,
which serves as an incentive program to save money. The centralized university sets these
targets and controls the minimum
amount a school can increase its
tuition, above which it may do
what it likes, keeping the surplus.

Stobo adds that "chance favors
the prepared mind." If someone
is prepared to ask the simple
questions, chance will allow him
to ask such questions. Stobo emphasizes the "mind as a research
tool." He says that certain
qualities are essential for the
curious nature: persistence, the
courage to ask the question and
pursue the answer, perceptiveness, and the ability to listen.
He says that these qualities can be
developed, and are therefore
available to all those who desire
them. Genetic qualities, such as
intelligence and creativity are less
important.
The conclusion that Stobo
reaches is not necessarily a
pessimistic one. He says that intellectual curiosity can be
stimulated, despite the constraints
of a competitive academic environment. Hopkins is "committed to make chart makers, and not
just readers." If the faculty and
staff act as role models for the
future scientists, then they too
will be able to ask the simple
questions that need answers.

Seniors comment on Athletics
The following two articles are
the first in a series designed to
give senior athletes a chance to
speak about the Athletic Department at Hopkins. Greg Bronshvag must be thanked for the
time he spent conducting these interviews and writing these
articles.

Craig Weinstein will graduate
in May with a B.A. in Economics
after lettering four times in soccer. He made the All-MAC team
the past three years (first-team
twice, honorable-mention once)
and was nominated for Division
III All-American in 1986. In the
Hopkins record books, he ranks
first in career assists, fourth in
career goals, and first in overall
points scored.
"Over the yea's, the style of
play (at Hopkins) has changed a
lot, going from a kick-and-run
team to a more ball-control,
European-style team. We've done
no better than we should have.
We never beat a team that we
shouldn't have beaten. Something
was lacking.
"When we went to the NCAAs
in 1986, we played very well
together. When the coach
(Tierney) quit for another job
afterwards, the soccer program
could've gone one of two ways:
Become even better by pushing
soccer and hiring a full-time,
qualified soccer coach—like football, basketball, fencing, wrestling, baseball, and lacrosse
teams—or stay the same by hiring a part-time coach with no time
for recruiting and building a team
in the off-season.
"The coaching situation is one
that not too many people in the
soccer program are happy with,
except possibly for Mr. Scott,
who designed it so that an assistant lacrosse coach also takes the
responsibility of head soccer
coach. Coach Haus has come a
long way. He was put in an extremely tough situation, because
he's never played soccer before.
If someone offered me the headsoccer-coach job at Duke or some
other great program and told me
I would also have to coach
lacrosse, I'd take it. But that
wouldn't be fair to the lacrosse
players.
"Mr. Scott supports us and
wants us to win, but he doesn't
want us to win as much as we did.
When you've got players putting
in at least thirty hours a week
think he needs to be even more
supportive. To him, winning
eight games is a good season. It's
frustrating when everyone on the
team wants to win more than the
A.D. wants you to.
"I'd say that we were one of
the best teams in Division III soccer the past two years. There
wans't one team that we couldn't
have beaten. Still, we kept playing the same level of competition

year after year instead of scheduling better teams.
"I've given a bleak outlook of
the program, but there's a
tradeoff. If the school pushed soccer, like lacrosse, then it wouldn't
be as much fun. It wouldn't feel
like our team. The soccer team is
ours. The only pressure to win
came from the players
themselves. It's just great to play.
I hope that, in the future, the program will continue to improve.
"The truth of the matter is that
things aren't equal. The basketball team gets new shoes every
year, and the baseball team gets
new uniforms and dugouts. When
you see that, and know that
everyone else on the team sees it,
you get upset. A really nice grass
field would be great instead of the
lower field. You can tell that the
money and attention isn't being
put into soccer, which is
frustrating."
However, when Weinstein
looks back on it all, the positives
come to mind first.
"Making the NCAAs will
always be a highlight. Also, pulling together in some close games,
and a certain goal or two. Mainly, just winning and having a
great time with my friends."
Weinstein has excelled off the
field as well. He is a member of
a fraternity, has helped inner-city
kids in the Hopkins Tutorial Program, and has been on the Dean's
List the past two years.
"Hopkins is as good as a
school can be academically. It
puts a lot of emphasis on
yourself, which forces you to
motivate yourself. It's been a
great time for me."

Brian Dulin will graduate in
May with a B.S. in Electrical
Engineering after lettering four
times in football. He finished his
career at running back with 1,813
career yards, placing him third on
the Hopkins All-Time Leading
Rushers' list. He was honored in
1986 as the football team's
outstanding sophomore, and this
past year as the outstanding senior
contributor.
"A lot of people would say that
the football program has gone
from good to bad, but that's not
true. It's improved as the adminstration has paid more attention to it by letting Coach Pfeifer
bring in more players. However,
he brings in quantity, not quality. He should bring players in
from high schools with a tradition
of winning."
Dulin went to Father Judge
High School, whose football team
won the tough Philadelphia
Catholic League three of his four
years.
"I know what it's like to win,
but sometimes I think that only
half of our team knows that feeling. My freshman year, we had

a winning record, and I expected
the team to get better with every
year. After that season, there
seemed to be a transition in
leadership at the QB position,
which is so vital to the offense.
No one could step in and be a
leader. Part of the problem was
that coach Pfeifer, who always
prepares well for a game, would
abandon somettimg if it didn't
work immediately, which usually resulted in a player being yanked. That takes away your
confidence.
"On any level—high school,
college, or pro—if you go 1-9,
the first place everyone looks is
at the head coach, whether or not
it's his fault. The coaching.staff
(at Hopkins) should be switched
that Coach Pfeifer, who always
fensive coordinator, but as a head
coach, he is not a great motivator.
He gets a bum rap, even though
off the field he's a super person.
But it takes more to be a great
coach than that. You have to
relate to the players and not allow
them to get down on themselves.
"But there's more to all this.
Overall, the team needs to be
more serious. For instance, not
everyone works out when they're
supposed to. It's not good for the
freshmen to have suffered
through a season like this past
one. A lot of talking needs to be
done between the coaches and
playes. Also, the team needs to be
put on a strict weightlifting
schedule, which everyone should
follow.
"Next year's team already has
the best talent in the [Centennial]
league, but it will all depend on
the players deciding for
themselves to change their attitude, start working hard, and
follow the coaches instead of being against them. This team can
go far in a very competitive
league. The possibility of
Hopkins getting an NCAA bid
exists. The team can only go in
one direction, and that's up.
Positive things can happen, but
the way things are right now, the
first game of the season is going
to make or break the team next
year."
Dulin could have gone to
Carnegie-Mellon, Gettysburg,
Wagner, Widener, or an Ivy
League school to play football.
Yet he chose Hopkins.
"I wanted to go to a place
where, even if I got hurt playing
football, I wouldn't have to worry
because academics would have
been there all along. I knew I
wasn't going to the pros, but I
still wanted to play. At an Ivy
school, I wouldn've been sitting
for two or three years before I got
a chance. I'm not willing to sit on
the bench and say I'm part of a
team. Academics and playing
football were both possible at
Hopkins.
"The academics are tough
here, and the school could do a
lot more for its students. I taught
myself half of my courses
because certain professors cared
more about their research than
their teaching. Still, Hopkins has
been a good experience for me.
I don't think I wouldn've made it
here without my friends I'll
always remember my friends first
and football second."

ALL MAC SOUTHEAST
MEN'S BASKETBALL TEAM

Varsity 8 takes on water in closing race
by Bart Taylor
YELLOW
PRESS—
Chestertown, Maryland is a picturesque eastern shore town,
situated on the Chester River.
This Saturday it was the site of an
invitation race, hosted by
Washington College. Crews attending were Hopkins, St. Johns,
and William & Mary. The informal atmosphere made for a
leisurely wait as crews rigged
their boats and prepared for their
races.
First to compete was the
"Justice League" men's novice
eight, and they came away victorious. Two of the rowers wore
special racing wigs (all the rage

this season). Washington College
crossed the finish line a full
seventeen seconds later, with
William & Mary and St. Johns in
tow.
The varsity four category was
Hopkins's show entirely. The
Hopkins heavyweight four edged
out the Hopkins lightweights by
three seconds. Washington College's A and B boats lagged sixteen seconds behind. Vito
Carluci, stroke
of the
lightweights, contends, "Those
guys [the heavyweights]just think
they won. The angle of the finish
was tricky—it was an illusion."
Next race up was the women's
novice eight category. The race
was close all around, and

Hopkins took second place to
Washington College, despite a
ragged finish. The women
defeated St. Johns—a crew that
beat them in a close contest at the
Occoquan—as well as William &
Mary.
Hopkins garnered another firstplace standing in the women's
varsity four category. Last
week's windy mishap ws forgotten as the four outstripped the
competition by a huge margin.
Washington's A and B boats, as
well as William and Mary, were
left in the dust (or spray). By this
point in the afternoon, the
weather was picking up and the
Chester river was becoming
choppy.

by Alex Salkever
This year's Spring Fair will
boast a bigger and better arts and
crafts, according to co-chairs
Kelly Mansfield and Linda Mirsky. The Upper and Lower
Quads will be filled with arts and
crafts booths for all three days of
the fair.
At this year's Fair, about thirty more arts and crafts vendors
will be here, compared to last
year's Fair. "About half of the
vendors are here for the first
time," said Mirsky. She said that
the vendors' offerings at this
year's Fair are more diverse than
those last year. Some of the new
vendors will sell inlaid wood
crafts, stained glass, wind
chimes, handmade flutes, and
handpainted Ukrainian Easter
eggs.
Mirsky said, "Even in the
more common arts and crafts,
such as jewelry. . .there will be
diverse types of media used to
make these crafts." Some examples of these diverse media are
jewelry made out of electronic
circuits, paper, brass, ivory, and
the traditional precious metals.
She also said that the quality of
the arts and crafts offered at Fair
will be exceptionally high. Referring to last year's vendors, Mirsky said, "If their stuff wasn't up
to the same quality level or was
manufactured, then they were not
asked back." She added, "We
have very high quality stuff this
year."
Mansfield and Mirsky scouted
new talent for Fair at a large arts
and crafts fair that took place this
spring at the Inner Harbor. The
vendors this year are from as far
away as Tennessee and Vermont,

although many are from the local
community. Commenting on the
ease with which the arts and
crafts committee attracted talent
this year, Mirsky said, "This Fair
has a very good reputation."
Asked how this year's
Maritime '89 theme fits in with
arts and crafts, Mirsky said the
theme was especially popular
with local vendors because
". . .the harbor is the center of
life in Baltimore." Many of the
crafts offered this year will be
centered on the maritime theme.
Some of these offerings include
driftwood sculptures, seashell
crafts, maritime theme silk
screening, harbor prints, and fish
earrings. According to Mirsky,
the vendors are going out of their
way to incorporate this year's
theme into their crafts displays.
This year's Fair also offers a
number of crafts booths for
children. One of the most notable
of these is a vendor who makes
mask kits for children called
"Curiosity Kits." Each kit is based on a real type of mask and
comes with an explanation of the
history behind the mask. These
kits are handmade especially for
children as educational toys.
Several other booths that
should be interesting for children
are the handcarved Chinese
checkers board booth, the wood
toys booth, and the handprint tshirt booths.
Two of the more exotic attractions will be a Tarot card reader
and a glass blower. The glass
blower will demonstrate from

by Steven Mizrach
"Maritime '89." When else would you see inflatable tubes on the
library?
The Spring Fair Theme Committee has been hard at work on several
projects. This year's theme committee chairs are seniors Michael Falk
and Grace Kung, and junior Nelson Tang. This year's theme is
nautical, hence the theme of Spring Fair is "Maritime '89."
The group's fifteen members have been meeting regularly since the
beginning of January. As often happens, the group dismissed some
of its initial ideas as "farfetched," such as turning Gilman Hall into
a lighthouse.
The committee decided to divide the campus into several areas: the
area in front of the Milton S. Eisenhower Library would appropriately
be called the "Beach," complete with artificial surf; especially for
kids area would become the "Pirates' Cove," with ambling buccaneers; the Upper Quad would be the "Upper Harbor," with sails
and nautical flags; and the Lower Quad would turn into "Ten Thousand Leagues Beneath the Sea," complete with underwater creatures.
Since the traditional releasing of balloons is considered too much
of an environmental hazard, Fair chairs will instead dedicate the ship
S.S. Hopkins to begin the Fair. Tony Pagnotti, a reporter for WMARTV, will have the honors. As part of nighttime entertainment, the
Glass Pavilion will be turned into a "fishbowl," and the Great Hall
will be considered the deck of a ship.
Most of the committee's work in the last few weeks has involved
decorating the campus. It has been busy designing the banners with
the different area designations, and has also been making wooden
cutouts of waves and sea creatures such as octopi and jellyfish. The
group has been trying to obtain tires to use as the hump of a giant
sea monster, and to get nautical flags from the United States Coast
Guard.
Tang said, "The Theme Committee must be really dedicated, or
Spring Fair wouldn't be a cohesive whole." He said that the many
worked with other committees to incorporate many different aspects
of Fair into the theme, so that by Friday everything would "fit in.,,
All the other committees, he pointed out, can sometimes lose sight
of the theme in the day-to-day "hustle and bustle" of arranging events,
so the theme committees must make sure that the central theme is
fully represented in the Fair.

NEWS-LETTER/11

Imported beer,
seafood available
by Andrea Marsh
"We think we've made some changes
which will help everyone in the long run,"
said Jon Aronson, co-chairman of the
Beer/Soda Committee.
The major change is that this year an imported beer, Beck's, will be available in the
beer garden.
"We're hoping it will go over real well,"
said Mike Holmes, also in charge of beer and
soda for Fair.
Last year, the seven booths in the beer
garden sold both beer and wine coolers.
However, Holmes said that the problem was
that a great demand for coolers. As a result,
this year only one booth will sell California
Coolers.
"Since wine coolers don't sell as well, it
didn't make sense for all the booths to have
them," said Aronson.
Holmes and Aronson anticipate that by concentrating all the coolers in one place, they
hope to sell the equivalent of ten kegs, more
than in past years.
Five booths will sell Schaefer beer ($1
each), one will sell Beck's ($1.25 each), and
the other booth will have California coolers
($1 each). All beer will be sold in the President's Garden.
Pepsi and Pepsi Light will be available at
booths on the Lower and Upper Quads for
seventy-five cents apiece. One soda booth will

be in the beer garden.
Aronson said he and Holmes saw no need
to change the way the soda booths were
organized.
"There was no indication of a problem,"
he said. "Of course, the fewer groups we
have, the more money each group makes, but
that also means less participation by student
groups."
Both Aronson and Holmes are excited about
the evening parties. Both Michelob and
Michelob Lite will be available for $1. In the
past, Schaefer was served both nights.
"It's the most premium beer we've ever
had," said Holmes. "We're real excited
about that."
Jenna Janss, co-chair of the Food committee, is also enthusiastic about this year's Fair.
"There's a lot more student participation than
in the past," she said.
This year, fourteen student groups are having food booths, more than in previous years.
Many other students are working with professional groups.
According to Janss, Fair has contracted for
fifty food booths, seeking more diversity.
Several new vendors include Lee's Ice Cream
and Talkin' Turkey, a deli specializing in
turkey sandwiches.
"We tried to get other things besides the
greasy fast food," she said.
More food will be in the beer garden this
year. Domino's will sell pizza, and crabs will

be available for the first time ever.
The food booths will be spread over the
Lower Quad and the Upper Quad. However,
on Monday, arrangements had to be made to
move six booths.
According to Janss, the Department of
Psychology is conducting experiments with
rats in the basement of Ames Hall. The smell
of food supposedly can affect the rats, and
could change the outcome of the experiments.
As a result, no food booths wil be located on
either side of the stairways leading to the
Lower Quad.
Psychology Professor Stewart Hulse said
that these experiments are conducted every
year, and that the problem is not new.
"We're concerned about the general health
of the animals, but this is no big deal," he
said.
Janss disagreed, however, saying that moving the booths did cause "major problems.'
She said that this year is the first that the
booths had to be moved.
"It could have been easily dealt with if it
had been brought up earlier," she said. "But
on Monday before Fair, it has really caused
some inconvenience."
The major problem with moving the booths
was that the electrical wiring that had already
been laid down had to be moved.
Janss said, however, that the problem was
handled well. "Despite the inconvenience,"
she said, everyone has been really cooperative
and supportive in trying to work out the
problem."

8-K run for early rising runners
by Bradley Cohen
The fifth annual Spring Fair 8-kilometer race is set to begin in front
of the Newton H. White Athletic Center Saturday morning. The race,
with separate men's, women's, and Hopkins divisions will wind
around the Homewood campus finishing on the track.
A relatively new activity for Spring Fair, the race will attract approximately 225 runners, according to Skip Bacon, race committee
chair. The course begins in front of the Athletic Center, proceeds
along University Parkway and then down Charles Street to Wyman
Park. The course then works its way around the back of campus and
finishes at the track.
Bacon describes the race as a "fun run on the middle ground" between a 5K and 10K race. The committee thought that an 8K race
would be challenging, but not too long. The race was originally intended to promote health, not competition, but that has not deterred
serious competitors from entering the event.
Last year's male winner was Anthony Grier, who won with a time
of 26:00. The female winner was Pat Milleson, with a time of 30:19.

Sandy Saluzary won the Hopkins division with a time of 33.05. This
year Bacon predicts the competition to be as good as last year's, if
not better.
Planning for the race began at the start of the semester with a search
for sponsors. Bacon explained his method for finding sponsors: "You
basically ask them (sponsors] how much they will give," he said.
The sponsors put up $2,000 to pay for the race.
This year's sponsors include Schaefer beer, Domino's Pizza, and
Reebok shoes. Bacon said that all of the proceeds from the race go
to benefit the homeless of Baltimore.
After finding sponsors, Bacon and his committee had to plan the
course and seek city approval. "We've been working on things one
at a time," he said. Since receiving permission from the city, the committee has been busily promoting the race and signing up participants.
Anyone may register for the race on Friday at the Spring Fair office or just before the race on Saturday morning. Registration is $9
on Friday and $10 Saturday. Bacon said that anyone who would like
to help officiate should speak with him before the race. Everyone who
works will receive a free race t-shirt.

Commencement conclusions
News-Letter

Finally, a scant 41 days before graduation,
the senior class commencement committee has
snared a speaker. Kenneth Duberstein, former
chief of staff in the Reagan administration, will
address seniors in the afternoon of May 25.
While Duberstein is a relative unknown to
many, he will doubtless send seniors out into
the world with a rousing and challenging
address.
More interesting, perhaps, than the speaker
himself, has been the drama that has unfolded
in his selection. From late starts to lack of student participation to severe budget limitations,
the selection process has been plagued from the
very beginning. That we have snatched a
speaker from the jaws of defeat at all is tantamount to a miracle.
We should not, however, bog ourselves down
in the mire of rehashing the endless details of
this somewhat sad situation. Rather, we should
glean what lessons we can from the difficulties
that they have faced over the course of the year.
First, the senior class, if they are to attract a
speaker of reasonable caliber, ought to have
sufficient funding to support their expectations.
At present, there is $2500 budgeted for this purpose; on the lecture circuit more sought-after
speakers can fetch up to ten times as much.
For those universities that do not allot large
amounts of r9ch to comr—ncement speakers,

there is often compensation in the form of an
honorary degree for the speaker. At present,
the University has "strict policies" regarding
the granting of such degrees.
The offer of an honorary degree might
sweeten the pot for anyone considering speaking here; however, for this to occur, the
Trustees must be given advance notice and
deem the potential recipient as worthy of the
honor.
Which brings us to our final point:
possibilities for speakers must be compiled
earlier in the year than has been the practice
in years past. This year, despite the endless
disclaimers from senior class officers, there was
a serious dearth of publicity surrounding the
project. Senior Week, ostensibly the most important responsiblity of the senior class officers,
ought to be in full gear by the middle of the
first semester, soliciting opinions and compiling early lists in order to facilitate selection.
These options ought to be fully communicated
to the class throughout the year. We need only
look to the experiences of this year's class for
failures in this sort of rapport. It seemed seniors
heard little of any plan until it was a fait accompli; this individualistic style of leadership
created a sense of futility and further discouraged senior class involvement.

Securing a position
The appointment of Lou Giangiulio to the
search committee for a new Hopkins president
is an unexpected boon. After all, student contact with the Board of Trustees has been limited
to the occasional protest outside of Board
meetings. The Trustees have preferred to
receive their student viewpoint from the Young
Trustees, whose positions they created to meet
this specific need.
Events of the last year, however, have
demonstrated that undergraduates desire more
input into decisions that will affect them. The
February brouhaha over the Five-Year Plan was
due not
much to objections over the plan

itself, but rather to students' lack of involvement in its drafting and fears of being left out
of its implementation.
But it is noteworthy that the addition of a student to the committee is due to exhaustive efforts on the part of Giangiulio. Were it not for
his initiative, this in all probability would never
have occurred. We commend Giangiulio for his
energy and note the precedent that his appointment to the committee sets in terms of administrative sensitivity to student concerns. We
can only hope that it bodes well for further student involvement in the future.

Talent abounds at Showcase
by Eric Ruck
On Thursday, April 6, Shriver
Hall was filled not with a touring
band or a local performer, but
with thirteen students and student
groups, there to perform and
compete in Musical Showcase
1989, sponsored by the Office of
Residential Life.
The crowd present was
small—about the size of an
average Weekend Wonderflix
crowd on a Friday night. People
came and went as different performers took their turns; occasionally someone would disappear from the audience, only to
reappear on stage.
The Skid Row Pits played the
first set. They were, according to
senior Sharon Finberg, reminiscent of the Blues Brothers, and
lived up to their name.
"It was a little slower than I've
heard the tunes before," she said,
"but it was a good opening to the
show."

Next were Phil Garrant and
The Great Highland Bagpipe;
Michele D. Pineda playing a
Debussy toccata; Paul Zei and
James Dante playing Mancini's
"Moon River"; and Erika
Horsey's "Product of Inspiration," an original piece written
for guitar.
"She was inspired," said
senior Ginger Marth. "She had
a really rich voice, and a good
composition. The sound equipment started to fall apart, but she
didn't get phased."
Geetha Rao and Floyd Bullard
played Schubert's Military March
just before The JHU Gospel
Choir took the stage. Anyone
who has walked on the lower
quad during one of the choir's
rehearsals and heard the singing
as far away as Maryland Hall can
imagine how this group can fill a
theater with sound.
"They were very energetic,"
said Committee member John
Tennison. "I don't know whether

Hopkins students have seen that
sort of thing before."
After a ten-minute intermission, Lovejoy and his Nuclear
Band of Half-Naked & Wild
Boys, consisting of Franklin
Sechriest (Lovejoy) and Mike
Datto (ostensibly the Nuclear
Band), took the stage. Lovejoy
opened with a guitar solo that had
the audience clapping; Datto joined in on saxophone for a rendition of "Stray Cat Strut," during
which Lovejoy's maniacal
laughter drew some applause.
Master of Ceremonies Alice
Griffin then introduced Lou
Giangiulio and his accordion "so
that the Class of 1992 can be as
overwhelmed as the rest of us."
Julia G. Ro then played Mozart's
Turkish March, and was followed by Saxual 4-play, which performed Lucien Cailliet's "Fantasy and Fugue on O'Suzanna."

Difficulties occur in financing A&S
by Paul Kramer
Part two of two
Dr. Steven McLean, Hopkins's
Vice Provost for Academic Planning and Budget, who represents
Hopkins in the Ten College Consortium, noted that to deal with
economic pressures, Duke has instituted a tuition differential plan
such as Hopkins's and begun a
major capital campaign to increase its endowment. This will
raise capital for the construction
of new buildings, allow
strengthening of library and
financial aid facilities, and help
Duke move up in prestige.
Case Western Reserve, according to Provost Richard Zdonis,
former Vice Provost at Hopkins,
is more centralized than the
Hopkins model All budgeting is

done by the central administration, which allows greater
amounts of interdisciplinary
research and teaching. Each of
the three faculties (Engineering,
Science and Math, and Arts and
Social Sciences) gives a mandatory tax to a reserve fund that
supports weaker divisions, and
although the faculties are selfcontained, they are operated as a
fiscal whole; the surpluses from
each go back into the main
college.
Columbia University has a fairly decentralized model, although
not as decentralized as Hopkins.
As explained by Dr. Michael
Mooney, deputy Provost, the
University is divided into units,
or schools; each forms a budget
from endowments it specifically
receives The centralized administration has control over the

unrestricted money, which it
allocates the units according to a
formula. The "Arts and Sciences
Construct" is the largest of the
unrestricted budgetary units.
Aside from these unrestricted
allotments, the units are given
freedom to budget their own programs as they see fit. Each unit
is given a target that is the difference between budgeted
revenues and budgeted expenses.
If in one unit revenues are greater
than expected, or expenses less,
the unit may keep its profit,
which serves as an incentive program to save money. The centralized university sets these
targets and controls the minimum
amount a school can increase its
tuition, above which it may do
what it likes, keeping the surplus.

Stobo adds that "chance favors
the prepared mind." If someone
is prepared to ask the simple
questions, chance will allow him

qualities are essential for the
curious nature: persistence, the
courage to ask the question and
pursue the answer, perceptiveness, and the ability to listen.

developed, and are therefore
available to all those who desire
them. Genetic qualities, such as
intelligence and creativity are less
important.

pessimistic one. He says that intellectual curiosity can be

of a competitive academic environment. Hopkins is "committed to make chart makers, and not

staff act as role models for the
future scientists, then they too
will be able to ask the simple
questions that need answers.

Seniors comment on Athletics
The following two articles are
the first in a series designed to
give senior athletes a chance to
speak about the Athletic Department at Hopkins. Greg Bronshvag must be thanked for the
time he spent conducting these interviews and writing these
articles.

Craig Weinstein will graduate
in May with a B.A. in Economics
after lettering four times in soccer. He made the All-MAC team
the past three years (first-team
twice, honorable-mention once)
and was nominated for Division
III All-American in 1986. In the
Hopkins record books, he ranks
first in career assists, fourth in
career goals, and first in overall
points scored.
"Over the yea's, the style of
play (at Hopkins) has changed a
lot, going from a kick-and-run
team to a more ball-control,
European-style team. We've done
no better than we should have.
We never beat a team that we
shouldn't have beaten. Something
was lacking.
"When we went to the NCAAs
in 1986, we played very well
together. When the coach
(Tierney) quit for another job
afterwards, the soccer program
could've gone one of two ways:
Become even better by pushing
soccer and hiring a full-time,
qualified soccer coach—like football, basketball, fencing, wrestling, baseball, and lacrosse
teams—or stay the same by hiring a part-time coach with no time
for recruiting and building a team
in the off-season.
"The coaching situation is one
that not too many people in the
soccer program are happy with,
except possibly for Mr. Scott,
who designed it so that an assistant lacrosse coach also takes the
responsibility of head soccer
coach. Coach Haus has come a
long way. He was put in an extremely tough situation, because
he's never played soccer before.
If someone offered me the headsoccer-coach job at Duke or some
other great program and told me
I would also have to coach
lacrosse, I'd take it. But that
wouldn't be fair to the lacrosse
players.
"Mr. Scott supports us and
wants us to win, but he doesn't
want us to win as much as we did.
When you've got players putting
in at least thirty hours a week
think he needs to be even more
supportive. To him, winning
eight games is a good season. It's
frustrating when everyone on the
team wants to win more than the
A.D. wants you to.
"I'd say that we were one of
the best teams in Division III soccer the past two years. There
wans't one team that we couldn't
have beaten. Still, we kept playing the same level of competition

year after year instead of scheduling better teams.
"I've given a bleak outlook of
the program, but there's a
tradeoff. If the school pushed soccer, like lacrosse, then it wouldn't
be as much fun. It wouldn't feel
like our team. The soccer team is
ours. The only pressure to win
came from the players
themselves. It's just great to play.
I hope that, in the future, the program will continue to improve.
"The truth of the matter is that
things aren't equal. The basketball team gets new shoes every
year, and the baseball team gets
new uniforms and dugouts. When
you see that, and know that
everyone else on the team sees it,
you get upset. A really nice grass
field would be great instead of the
lower field. You can tell that the
money and attention isn't being
put into soccer, which is
frustrating."
However, when Weinstein
looks back on it all, the positives
come to mind first.
"Making the NCAAs will
always be a highlight. Also, pulling together in some close games,
and a certain goal or two. Mainly, just winning and having a
great time with my friends."
Weinstein has excelled off the
field as well. He is a member of
a fraternity, has helped inner-city
kids in the Hopkins Tutorial Program, and has been on the Dean's
List the past two years.
"Hopkins is as good as a
school can be academically. It
puts a lot of emphasis on
yourself, which forces you to
motivate yourself. It's been a
great time for me."

Brian Dulin will graduate in
May with a B.S. in Electrical
Engineering after lettering four
times in football. He finished his
career at running back with 1,813
career yards, placing him third on
the Hopkins All-Time Leading
Rushers' list. He was honored in
1986 as the football team's
outstanding sophomore, and this
past year as the outstanding senior
contributor.
"A lot of people would say that
the football program has gone
from good to bad, but that's not
true. It's improved as the adminstration has paid more attention to it by letting Coach Pfeifer
bring in more players. However,
he brings in quantity, not quality. He should bring players in
from high schools with a tradition
of winning."
Dulin went to Father Judge
High School, whose football team
won the tough Philadelphia
Catholic League three of his four
years.
"I know what it's like to win,
but sometimes I think that only
half of our team knows that feeling. My freshman year, we had

a winning record, and I expected
the team to get better with every
year. After that season, there
seemed to be a transition in
leadership at the QB position,
which is so vital to the offense.
No one could step in and be a
leader. Part of the problem was
that coach Pfeifer, who always
prepares well for a game, would
abandon somettimg if it didn't
work immediately, which usually resulted in a player being yanked. That takes away your
confidence.
"On any level—high school,
college, or pro—if you go 1-9,
the first place everyone looks is
at the head coach, whether or not
it's his fault. The coaching.staff
(at Hopkins) should be switched
that Coach Pfeifer, who always
fensive coordinator, but as a head
coach, he is not a great motivator.
He gets a bum rap, even though
off the field he's a super person.
But it takes more to be a great
coach than that. You have to
relate to the players and not allow
them to get down on themselves.
"But there's more to all this.
Overall, the team needs to be
more serious. For instance, not
everyone works out when they're
supposed to. It's not good for the
freshmen to have suffered
through a season like this past
one. A lot of talking needs to be
done between the coaches and
playes. Also, the team needs to be
put on a strict weightlifting
schedule, which everyone should
follow.
"Next year's team already has
the best talent in the [Centennial]
league, but it will all depend on
the players deciding for
themselves to change their attitude, start working hard, and
follow the coaches instead of being against them. This team can
go far in a very competitive
league. The possibility of
Hopkins getting an NCAA bid
exists. The team can only go in
one direction, and that's up.
Positive things can happen, but
the way things are right now, the
first game of the season is going
to make or break the team next
year."
Dulin could have gone to
Carnegie-Mellon, Gettysburg,
Wagner, Widener, or an Ivy
League school to play football.
Yet he chose Hopkins.
"I wanted to go to a place
where, even if I got hurt playing
football, I wouldn't have to worry
because academics would have
been there all along. I knew I
wasn't going to the pros, but I
still wanted to play. At an Ivy
school, I wouldn've been sitting
for two or three years before I got
a chance. I'm not willing to sit on
the bench and say I'm part of a
team. Academics and playing
football were both possible at
Hopkins.
"The academics are tough
here, and the school could do a
lot more for its students. I taught
myself half of my courses
because certain professors cared
more about their research than
their teaching. Still, Hopkins has
been a good experience for me.
I don't think I wouldn've made it
here without my friends I'll
always remember my friends first
and football second."

guys [the heavyweights]just think

Washington College, despite a
ragged finish. The women

Occoquan—as well as William &
Mary.

week's windy mishap ws forgotten as the four outstripped the
competition by a huge margin.
Washington's A and B boats, as
well as William and Mary, were
left in the dust (or spray). By this
point in the afternoon, the
weather was picking up and the
